content:
y 6, 2016
What is Crusader Kings 2?Explaining what Crusader Kings 2 is is difficult. There are 9 "Major" DLC"s for this game, which add as much content as the base game, and drastically opens the game. So what Crusader Kings 2 is, greatly depends on which DLC"s you get. What this game is though at its core, is a real time strategy game set in the medieval era's, the base game is from 1066 to 1453. The DLC's The Old Gods and Charlemagne allow for a start date of 867 and 769, respectively, allowing for over 700 years of game-play through the early dark ages, all the way to the beginning of the Rennaissance period. You can start playing as a Duke of a few provinces, under a King. A King, or an Emperor. Through this time, you will be restricted by realistic "rules and laws" which governed the world at that time as you balance your lands among your vassals, and family. Keeping the Feudal system together, your people happy, and making sure vassals don't revolt, is much tougher than you'd think. You could start off as a King with 40 Vassals, 70 counties, and countless castles in your control, and in 200 years, find yourself owning nothing more than a half disseveled castle in a province nobody cares about, having lost your seat on the throne, to an usurping vassal who got the better of you. Or you could find yourself in the same situation in reverse, having bested your King on the field of battle, and taking the throne for your own. Holy Wars, cultural differences. Supporting, and or working against your King, or Emperor, vassalizing near by independent rulers, and sometimes, even attempting assassinations against your own family, are all things which you may need to do, to keep your next of heir securely in line for the throne, and your current holdings and estates safely in the family. The game revolves, not around the country, but your family. In Medieval ages, your family "house" is whats important. As your current ruler dies, you will take direct control of the next of heir of your house, and they will gain the titles which the laws of your country allow depending on succession laws. The politics are setup pretty realistically to how it was in those days as well. Marrying off a daughter is what made alliances, nothing else. (Not 100% accurate, but damn close enough to be considered "historical"). Succession laws of how your children are allowed to take the throne, greatly impacts your future as well. All in all if you love Medieval history, and want to learn more about how it worked, this game will teach you things you never knew. If you own Europa Universalis IV, there is a converter which you can get for Crusader Kings 2, Allowing you to convert the world exactly as it is from Crusader Kings 2, into Europa Universalis IV, allowing you to continue your reign of your Kingdom, as you move from the Medieval ages, into the age of Rennaissance and exploration.  There is no game that has better replayability than Crusader Kings 2. I have played nearly 400 different games, and have over 1000 hours in this game. (Before I got it on steam), and not a single one of my games has been remotely close to playing out like any other. -------------------The DLC'sI know there are some upheavels about the amount of DLC's, and some people screaming bloody murder and cash grab insults. I have to beg to differ, and I'd like to explain why if you're one of those people who have been hearing this. This game was released in Feb, 14th of 2012. That's 4 years as of this year in 2016. In those 4 years, Paradox has released 9 "Major" DLC's, which open the game up tremendously, and add in depth mechanics, new events, and great game changes, all of which are superb. (You can tell if it's a "Major" DLC if the price is over 1.99) These DLC's are not "DLC's", they are the equievalant of legit expansions from back in the day, when a developer would release an expansion to a game you had to pay for, which adds just as much as the base game originally had. The Old Gods for instance, allows you to play as the Pagans. All with their own 100's of new events for both pagan and non pagan leaders, new mechanics for the pagans, and opens the game up tremendously in that area, as well as pushing the start date back another 200 years. The Republic expansoin does, well what you think. Allows you to play as a Merchant Republic, such as Venice, AND allows any leader to setup a Merchant Republic within their own country, which greatly increases gold income. Playing as a Merchant Republic is vastly different than playing as a feudal lord, and is yet again another major expansion, adding 100's of new events, entirely new different type of game-play to play around if you're playing as a Merchant Republic, etc. The list goes on for every single one of those 9 "Major" DLC's. None of which are a rip off in anyway for the price because of how much each add to the game as a whole.  So what about those countless 1.99 stuff? This is where I can understand if people say "cash grab", however I personally would still disagree to some extent simply because being an Indie developer myself, I understand the work that does need to be put in to make it viable. Albeit it still isn't much work over all. The 1.99 little DLC's which change sprites on the map, or allow for more family house crest art to personally change, etc. its over all cheap, and it's entirely up to you to buy it or not. They however in no way take away from the game by not having them, and are all cosmetic. The ones I personal like are the ones which change the look of the people and their outfits, etc. to fit the time and appearance they'd of had for that culture and area in the world a bit more than the stock game. These are all very cheap however, 1.99 to about 3.99, depending on how much it adds, but all of which are about 10x cheaper than going to the movies, which only nets you 1 hour of annoyance while you try to enjoy it, and people decide now is a good time to be loud and annoying.. I'd rather pay the 7 small DLC's for the same price and fully enjoy it for the rest of my life... Step aside movies..

content:
er 23, 2016
												Do you enjoy unintentionally (or intentionally...?) marrying your younger siblings to your elderly parents, or conspiring to murder every member of your family, in order to work your way onto the throne? No? Well good, as that probably means you're perfectly sane.However, if you enjoy hilarious occurrences such as this in video games, (especially when they're entirely unplanned!) as well as plenty of random events to help mix things up, I have no doubt that you'll enjoy Crusader Kings II; as CK2 is essentially a peek into the lives of medieval murderers, sex-fiends, club-footed harelip Dukes, as well as many more different combinations of humorously incapable royals inbreeding their way to glory!UPDATE: After a whole string of expansions came out since originally writing this review in Feb 2012, I've decided to re-write it and have added in the list below, containing some of the more essential expansions, as not all are necessarily required:LEGACY OF ROME - This pack adds retinues and factions. As I recall it originally got a bad rap as it didn't unlock additional regions of the map to the player (like Sword of Islam, for example), but these days it really is a staple expansion, and adds a lot to the game.THE OLD GODS - Vikings! And an early start date. Honestly, I feel that the Norse add enough that this is worth putting on the 'essentials' list, as it does shake things up a bit, from the standard 'European feudal lord' formula. Might want to get this after playing a game or two of CK2 though, as a regular feudal lord, perhaps.WAY OF LIFE - I might get flak from some people by putting this into the 'essential' list, but it adds a lot more to do, during peace time. Plus Paradox has fixed the Europe-wide orgy caused by the 'seduction' focus being super-powerful, so it's not as crazy as it was right after its initial release. (For better or for worse! :P )And now for a "good to have, but maybe don't get it until you've played the game a few times" list. (Rolls right off the tongue, eh?)SONS OF ABRAHAM - Adds more options, events, etc. for the three Abrahamic faiths (Christianity, Judaism and Islam). Solid expansion, but not strictly required. Good for a second playthrough, or if it's on-sale when you first buy/play the game.CONCLAVE - Kind of goes hand-in-hand with WoL above, I feel. Adds more to do (particularly during peacetime) as you're not the sole power within your realm, as your council will try and gradually curb your power and become a force to be reckoned with - so don't underestimate your councilors! Definitely adds a fair bit more difficulty though, as this expansion can result in a lot more civil wars occurring, if you aren't adept at ingame diplomacy and gaining favours, etc. so you may want to save this for your second playthrough.SWORD OF ISLAM - Makes Muslim rulers playable, and adds in decadence mechanics for them. Good for a second or third playthrough, after you have your fill of playing as a Christian.THE REPUBLIC - Same as SoI above, except it makes Republics playable. Adds in trading post mechanics (among others) for more money-making opportunities.REAPER'S DUE - This pack expands upon the existing disease mechanics, and makes the Black Death a very real threat! It also allows you to hire a court physician, who will then proceed to cut your leg off and/or gouge your eye out, in order to cure your cold. Fun expansion, but not essential.CHARLEMAGNE - This adds in a start date even earlier than TOG's start. Good if you want extremely long games that wind up taking a heavily alt-history route, but be aware that Europe will most likely be occupied by 4-5 huge blobs by 1066, so it might become a bit of a slog, late-game.RAJAS OF INDIA - OK if you want to play in India, but be warned that unless you get a huge, sprawling empire going, there won't actually be much (if at all) interaction between India and the rest of the game world. Really, I think they could've just made this into a separate game mode/campaign option.

content:
7
												Since this is the game I played the most on Steam, I figured it was about time I reviewed it. Now, I don't approve Paradox DLC policy but I played my entire first game of about 90 hours as the empire of Britannia (All Hail Brittannia) without any DLC and the game was still very fun to play. So if the price of all the DLC scares you, give it a try without any DLC and, even once you decide to buy DLC, just get the one that you actually want. For example, I never even use the game music, I always just mute it and play my own playlist so I obviously won't ever get any of the songs DLC. That being said, even if the DLC do not scare you, this game is for hardcore strategy games fans. The first 5 hours of the game will be mostly you figuring everything out and theres really not much tutorials to help you out.If you can get past all that though, this is the most fun and deep strategy game I have ever played. There is almost nothing you can't do in this game. Wanna make your loyal little brother an anti-pope since the pope excommuniated you because the french king (who happens to be his best friend) really hate you? And then later go to war with that pope and make your little brother the official pope for every catholics. You can. I know you can do that cause I did. Wanna make your last born son your heir even though he has 6 older brothers because he has by far the best stats since he was born a genius. And then have to imprison all your other sons when they inevitably plot to murder him? You can. I know you can do that cause I did. Want to make Buddhist the official religion of everyone in Europe through war and oppression? You can. I know you can do that cause I did. History is yours to write however you want. Thats why I love this game.The game is also full of random events that always keep the game interesting. Hell, after almost 400 hours, I'm still running into random events that I hadn't seen before (it helps that Paradox sometimes add new ones.) So yeah, despite its flaws, this is my favorite game on Steam and I have no doubt that I will probably play another 400 hours of it eventually.Oh and by the way, when you start a new game, turn off shattered retreat and defensive pacts cause those really sucks and break the immersion. That patch was the worst idea Paradox ever had.

number of helpful: 110 of 149 people (74%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
, 2016
												Let's set things straight: this is one of the best Paradox game and probably my favourite one since it covers a period of time I like a lot and since it's less complex and tactical than other Paradox. It has got, instead, a great RPG component. An amazing mix which makes the game very addicting.Why the negative review? Because this game alone is almost nothing. It lets you play just a very small amount of countries. If you want the full game you must buy the DLCs... nothing new you could think. Well, the problem is there is a HUGE amount of DLCs and after years from the publishing of the main game they're still developing new one. They're getting always more useless, DLC after DLC, while the price gets higher (some of the last costs half the main game...LOL).As a loyal and old Paradox fan i get frustrated not only because they're obviously trying to get any cents out of my wallet, but mainly because after 4 (FOUR!) years I still can't enjoy the full game: whenever you start a new campaign (and a CK game can be pretty long and time consuming) they announce a new DLC with new features and new rules and you feel like you're playing an useless match and feel like abandoning it and wait for the new DLC. Problem is: when you get it, they have already announced a new one.Also, every DLC comes with patches which totally change the rules of the game and you have to learn them again and again and again. It's like playing an early access game, but I've always hated those and I would have avoided it if I had known.Basically they're policy with games lately has become: "let's publish an incomplete game and let's charge a lot with DLCs if they want to play its full version" and they're not the only company to do it, but when they finished the game they started to make useless DLCs (there's one of fantasy history in which aztecs invade Europe... which is not a great thing in a game of such historic realism) and to change the rules to worse just to justify new DLCs. They're literally to the point in which a great game is turning into a bad one.Saddest thing for a loyal customer like me was the DLC to convert CK2 games into EU4 games to continue a campaign there. So I, a huge fan who bought all of your games, get rewarded for this by being forced to pay 10 euro just for a crappy converter if I want to "fuse" together the Paradox games I possess? Nice policy Paradox...To give you an idea, today you need 165€ just to play the full game (without even considering the massive amount of graphic and soundtrack DLCs or the EU4 converter) and DLCs are still coming out. The game can be good but its not worth half of that price.You better wait till they start working on CK3 and stop squeezing money out of this game. Then maybe they'll lower the price of a 4 years old game (prices are still the same even for the main game) and you can buy a cheap package with all the DLCs.It's not worth a penny before that. You can trust someone who loved this and other Paradox games.

One day a great King named Karl came and conqured Bjorn's Lands. number of helpful: 36 of 36 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ber 25, 2016
												Crusader Kings II is, IMHO, Paradox's best game.  It's a grand strategy game that throws many of the popular complexities of the genre such as a complicated tech tree, deep strategic combat, and a rich economy and city building out the window for very simple implementations of each and replaces it all with one thing: interpersonal drama.  It's all about what other people have that you want and what you have that other people want, and it produces epic struggles, dramatic twists of fate, and wonderful soap opera fodder.  At the start of the game if you have a small nation, you can play it a bit like a standard 4X.  Locate a smaller neighbor with no major allies, conquer, repeat.  As your empire grows, however, you begin to need to split up your holdings among relatives and friends- a province here, a duchy there.  And then those people begin to want things, and have armies, and begin to plan among themselves.  And maybe you have too many children, and those who aren't getting enough of the land start to hate you.  And maybe your king dies and his underaged heir who fewer people like and nobody respects takes over under the care of one of your trusted vassels, who may even now be plotting regicide.  When that daughter you married off a decade ago and forgot about suddenly inheriets a third of the Holy Roman Empire due to an accident of inheritance laws and a suspiciously high mortality rate among the nobility?  The knives will begin to come out before the crown has had time to settle on her brow, and damage control doesn't even begin to cover what follows.  Play enough of this game, and familicide won't even be an interesting enough story to warrant telling your spouse about after another play session where you stayed up three hours later than you wanted it.  Crusader Kings II is big, and imposing, and takes a long time to play, but there's pretty much nothing like it out there.  It might take a dozen hours before you really get what's going on, and I suspect most people who even try it will bounce off of it without understanding why it's such a big deal.  If it bites into you, though, your time will be repaid with an endless array of amazing stories and crazy alternate histories of Europe.

content:
20
												Iam sorry Paradox, but i have to write this now. I realy like Crusader Kings II, as i played nearly 300 Hours and many more on a non-steam Version. You can have fun with these games, spend hour after hour with it. I will not say the game is bad or not worth a bit of money...but there is a big argument against this game, or i would say against the DLC-Policy of Paradox. It is just insane how this is managed. Just take a look at the numbers...Steam tells me all DLC cost more than 270€ now. Okay lets say half of that is stuff you dont need, content packs etc...still 135€ plus the game for 40€. Iam no new player and played from the first years on and bought everything when it came out. But do you even know how stupid it is if you have friends just starting the game and telling them which DLC they need and stuff? They release a new DLC every few months with a few new things. Often they are good and iam very exited. But the are not everytime worth all the money. And they must be making alot of money thinking about the price. And i know...they say we put out new DLC to get some money to further develop the game and the game will get new content as long as the people buy the DLCs. Okay, that may sound good at first. But how do other game studios manage their stuff? Do they need to get out new DLC every few months for 15-25€(DLC+Contentpack)? NO. And that is almost the price of the whole game. And a DLC might bring some new stuff but not half of the game. So it is just too expensive.But it does not stop there. Iam a real Paradox-Freak you could say. I play almost all their big titles, Victoria, Europa Universalis, Stellaris, City Skylines, Hearts of Iron...you name it, i played hundreds of hours. And almost everywhere it is the same b*llsh*t!!! I want to play some Crusader Kings? Have to buy 2-3 DLCs to be on the newest Version. Stellaris the same. HoI4 the same. Skylines the same. What is that? I was so hyped about Stellaris. And the game was only half done, felt hollow and now they probably want to go the EU4 way and fix it over the years with tons of DLC. I just cant stand it anymore. After these many years iam frustrated and angry. I dont want to support this any longer. And what i hate the most about it, that maybe in a few months, i have some money, theres a sale and i will buys this freakin DLC anyway. BUT I HATE THEIR POLICY! AND I STILL WANT TO PLAY THAT STUFF! THEY GOT ME AND THEY USE ME! Combining all their game i probably payed them over 1000€ already. *Put a bad word here*!But they could do it differently. Why not bring out REAL DLC or a decent Add-On. Or Victoria 3. Where the hell is Victoria 3? Victoria was the best game they made in my opinion. But whatever. Someday Paradox will see that their way is the wrong way. Many people i know think the same. They are ruining these great games.tl;dr:If you are looking for an advice...the game is fun and you will probably like it. But Paradox has a real ♥♥♥♥♥♥ DLC-Policy. After a few years you will hate them, just like me. (I wrote almost the same Review for other Paradox Games. Everywhere the same Thing)

er 17, 2016
												I bought this game about 2 years ago for Christmas while it was about 35% off along with Fallout 3 and Dishonored. The trailer for CK2 made me intensely excited for it so I could live out all of my medieval fantasies to my heart's content. Upon opening the game however, I found myself seriously outmatched by the game's steep learning curve. That, coupled with the fact that I had bought two other masterpieces, made it difficult for me to rationalize spending the hours it would take for me to truly get into the game. About 2 months later after beating Fallout 3 and Dishonored, I dedicated myself to learning CK2 and to this day, I regret not doing it earlier. For anyone who wonders why it is so difficult to learn this game, the answer is very simple. It was very difficult to be a successful ruler in the medieval era. How should you know what you can and cannot do without experience? With this in mind, I encourage everyone to buy this game and sink about 20 hours into the game before making their judgements. I am certain that you will think differently about your purchase by that point and truly feel that it was worth it.

number of helpful: 33 of 36 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
y 9, 2014
												"Power tends to corrupt, and absolute power corrupts absolutely." - Lord ActonThe Medieval Age wasn't the brightest moment in human history. War, Assassination, Torture, Greed, Betrayal; those are merely some of the words associated with the atrocities committed by the rulers of the realm. Some good and honest men have ruled, but most rulers couldn't resist the temptation from the power they wield; the power to rule. They were tempted to gain more power, and they are willing to use even the most atrocious of acts to gain it.Crusader Kings II gives players a taste of that power.Starting at any point from 1066 (Or 769 with a certain DLC enabled) to 1453, players are allowed to choose from a very large amount of historical characters that once ruled over a part of Europe and parts of Asia and Africa. From the lowliest duke to the highest emperor, the game has no final objective whatsoever, leaving players to create their own story and decide their own goals for their dynasty. Do you want to be the most prestigious family in the world? To work your way up and create an empire that will last for generations? Or simply to make sure your bloodline survives through all the coming conflict? Grand strategy games typically put players as an eternal invisible guiding force controlling a single country, viewing the world from above as a map as they manage the country’s Politics, Economy, Military, and Diplomacy through various factors. These games use simple visuals to accommodate the large scale gameplay. There are no fancy Total War-like massive battles or anything of sort. Almost every aspect of the game depends on numbers. In other words, the main part gameplay is to manage those numbers and the various factors affecting it to the player’s benefit.Crusader Kings II offers a sandbox grand strategy experience into a more personal level; giving players control over a single Catholic ruler (later DLCs adds the options to play as Muslim, Pagan, and Jewish rulers) and continue on as his/her heir after passing away. Instead of dealing with faceless countries, the more personal approach allows the game to have a large amount of characters, be it a lord or a simple courtier. Every character in the game has their own set of skills, traits, and relations with other characters. A major part of the game is managing the relationship between characters by various interactions. You can cement the loyalty of your vassals by keeping them happy with gifts and inviting them to feasts. You can increase the odds of success of an assassination plot by inviting treacherous people within your target's court. You can declare a war for a title your courtier has a claim on. Be wary as other characters could do it to you as well. The best option is to trust no one, not even your friends and relatives. These interactions increase the depth of Crusader King II's strategic gameplay in a very dynamic way.The trademark Paradox's grand strategy gameplay is still present, even if somewhat simplified by the time period. Politics are mostly done by the character interactions mentioned above; with the addition of a player-manageable council the players can use accomplish certain tasks. Economy is much more simplified, with very little emphasis on trade. Instead of training units to form standing armies, you form a temporary military force in time of war, then disband them when the war is over. Your military comes from raising levies both from your personally owned holdings and from your vassals. (Retinues were added with a DLC). Religion plays a major role in the game, with each religion having some unique gameplay mechanic that differ them from the rest; such as the Papacy for Catholics and Decadence for Muslims. While the strategy gameplay itself for most the most part lacks depth compared to other Paradox grand strategy titles, Crusader Kings II still stands on its own as a well-made and unique game.Crusader Kings II is visuals are simple, yet fitting for the game. The map is fully rendered in 3D, it’s nothing breathtaking, but you can still appreciate the beauty of its landscape; although you'll probably spend most of the time using the political map mode. The character portraits are a great mix of realism and cartoony art style which provides a variety of colorful characters faces.The musical score for the game is also worth praising. While not all the music in the game is memorable, they rarely distract you from the game, and for the most part they complement your playthrough with a variety of beautiful music fitting for the era.The game is without its flaws, of course. While the tutorial is an improvement from previous Paradox titles, you will still need to learn most of the game’s mechanics on your own by trial or error. While it could be a part of the fun of playing the game, some people may dislike it. I’ve encountered several minor bugs, but the game is fully playable as of now. Another minor complaint is the lack of naval combat. While historically there wasn’t a lot of naval combat at the era, I wish that navies could be more useful such as for blockading ports. But as for the time this review was written, the only use for navies is for troop transport.Describing everything about Crusader Kings II’s in detail would take a lot of time and energy. Both of which you could be using right now to purchase and experience Crusader Kings II on your own! (Or at least try the demo) Go and create your own story with your dynasty. Be patient and play as an honest, good natured ruler. Or fall to the temptation of power and spill the blood of anyone who stands in your way. The choice is yours.Deus Vult.

2, 2016
												At the time of writing, this $40 game has $240 of DLC available.Crusader Kings II is a great game - and I'm not using that word lightly, it's a GREAT game - but I can't recommend it.  I've put a lot of hours into this game (more than Steam has counted), but it's never been a fulfilling experience because of all the goddamed DLC.Listen, I'm no enemy to DLC, if a developer makes more content for their game, I'll pay to play it.  But the way Paradox does it is straight up insidious."This new update adds North Africa to the game......but you can't play there unless you buy the Sword of Islam DLC""The newest update adds all of India to the vanilla map.......but you can't play there unless you buy the Rajas of India DLC""We just added the entire Asian continent to the game.......but you can't play there unless you buy the Horse Lords DLC"DLC in this game isn't comparable to DLC in other games, it's not like it adds a weapon skin or an extra level.  Crusader Kings II DLC fundamentally changes the core gameplay of the game, and some things that have DRASTIC changes on how you play (such as the ability to have a standing army, form custom kingdoms, or even the existence of the Jewish religion) are hidden behind 4 years and $240 of DLC.To put it simply, I have never felt like I was playing a finished game.  Every time I turn it on, there's an ad for yet another piece of DLC.  Once I finally save up enough to buy the next biggest DLC pack, another is announced.  It's just not fulfilling.Until Paradox decides to wrap this game up like they've done with Europa Universalis IV and Hearts of Iron III, and put their energy to developing Crusader Kings III instead of squeezing more DLC money out of current players, I can't recommend it.

content:
er 5, 2014
												Crusader Kings II on first look seems like just another game styled after so many other well-known games that use an overhead map and a time period. That’s where things steer into a different direction. This game may well be the best game created by the game smiths at Paradox Development Studio. It’s a huge strategy game with layers. I would suggest running the tutorial in the game. In fact I would also suggest keeping the hints option on, it is full of valuable playing information.Taking place over a 400 year time span the players take on the persona of a character running the realms and struggling to make it in these troublesome times.Throughout the game life, the character deals with the world and other characters of the court, they have stats and traits; they marry, and have children in hopes of conceiving an heir to the throne. That is the main point too, having a legitimate heir to the kingdom. As that first main character grows older and or dies before their time, as long as there is an heir the game goes on to 1452. Hierarchy and the bloodline are of some importance in this game as it was in yee olden days.The game plays in different ways depending on how the player chooses to start. Hierarchy plays a role here. So if the player starts out as a lower rank of the upper class, say a Count, well you have some leveling to do. There is so much information to be had during game play it can be over whelming at times; thankfully Paradox Development Studio has integrated so many buttons and drop downs to assist the player in keeping track of events and information. Plus the game can be paused to take a break or assess the situation. The interface and game play seems polished enough, though the animations took some getting used to.As gaming goes in the grand strategy style, there is some replay ability here, with so much going on, try different playing styles, be aggressive, or less so. See how things turn out, be a tyrant if you like.The graphics of the lands and seas are beautiful to behold, with clouds shadow and weather passing over the lands as you look down from your almost celestial view from above. Sound is pleasing as well, with music and sound bites setting the mood for events appropriately. This is truly one of the better games to come out from Paradox Development Studio, now like most strategy games, things do not progress always at a fast pace. So some patience in gaming is involved here. Crusader Kings II is exactly the sort of game I was hoping it would be. As deep and complex as its predecessor, but more accessible.

content:
27, 2016
												Ultimately, after 200 hours on a game (I'm not really a gamer so 200 hours is _insane_ for me to spend on a game) like this, you'd think I could recommend Crusader Kings II. Sadly, I am just not able to anymore. My view of CKII is pretty mixed, so I'll try to give the good with the bad. I'll start with the good first, since I plan to expand more on the bad.THE GOOD-The map is gorgeous and easily the best looking of all of Paradox's games. -Music, even without the music pack DLCs, is pretty great and I've never really gotten tired of it.-The history is, at least on the surface, simulated pretty well and I enjoy having some of the weirder and obscure characters in history able to be played like the last Karling, a random Christian ruler in Seljuk Anatolia, and so on. It's nice that they'll include stuff like that even if you can only access it by skipping to a very specific year.-The early DLCs, particularly The Old Gods, are genuinely fun. I love playing as the Norse during the Age of the Vikings and it's honestly one of the best parts of the game. It's to the point I almost wish The Old Gods was spun off as a different game (similar to For the Glory) to focus on just that era and expand more into Viking clans, religion, etc.-Unlike most I've played Crusader Kings 1 extensively and while there are a lot of steps back from that game, I do like that the council does more than just improve ruler stats. Letting your council micro-manage your realm (before they ruined it with Conclave) is genuinely very fun and makes it feel more like an actual feudal state.-It got me, someone who doesn't really like video games enough to be called a "gamer" (most of the games on my Steam are gifts are stuff I bought and never played), to play for 200 hours so that's got to count for something.THE BAD-First off, the DLCs. Holy ♥♥♥♥, the DLCs. Paradox, when I am expected to pay $15 to play as a Jew, when there are literally fewer than 10 Jewish players to even play in nearly _700 years_ of gameplay, how do you even justify that? Really, the DLCs have turned a good $60 game into a bloated mess that Paradox wants you to pay nearly $200 for. Even as someone with the means to do so, this game does _not_ deserve that price and is simply not good enough for it. I've bought strategy games for the PC that start at $100 retail because they are done with mind-boggingly amounts of research, study, and care. Crusader Kings II is not that good.-Besides the price of the DLCs, which is crazy, the amount of content that you have to add on to the game is out of control. Not only does it mean the base game is almost worthless, but that you start to break your game the more you add on to it. It is simply ridiculous and is something that warns off new players when they see mountains of DLC.-Patches that you have no control over that break your game. I am one of the poor people who bought Conclave on Day 1 and even though I have since turned it off like any sensible person, the forced patch means that I can't escape some of the worse parts of the DLC whether I want it or not. Paradox breaks your game for you and there is no real way to go back. I miss the days of the old Paradox games when I refused to upgrade EU 3 for over a year until better patches came around.-Conclave. Just...♥♥♥♥ing Conclave. If you want to know why it's so bad read one of the other reviews but suffice to say it breaks any sense of believability or historical playability of the game and turns it into a game that is almost impossible to play if you are anything more than a duke, and a minor duke at that. -Speaking of which...Paradox, either accept that your games are, you know, games or try to be more historical. You can't be either. Iqta government is not feudalism, CK II can't even begin to simulate medieval economies, and India. Didn't. Work. That. Way. I am a history nerd myself and that's why I enjoy Paradox games, but the way the game has been lately with the recent expansions it is almost impossible to try to play a game historically with the way that CKII works. Economy is a joke, armies don't work how they should, vassals aren't simulated anywhere near realistically, rebellions happen more often than they should for some countries and never for others (I have yet to see the Golden Horde have any problem ruling all of Russia past 1300 and often survives all the way to the end of the game fully intact).-A lot of the bad things in the game feel like a step back from Crusader Kings 1, which is one of my best games ever to this day. Events are basically nerfed and pointless now which severely hampers roleplaying, different numbers for a vassal's opinion of you and loyalty are gone which makes holding empires together almost impossible, armies and economy are massively changed and almost never for the better, and in general CK II just feels...less in depth. In Crusader Kings I, despite a smaller scope, I could really get lost into the intricacies of day-to-day rule. By this point in CK II with all the patches I rarely if ever care who my king is and never interact with him. I can't remember the last time it mattered who I marry beyond alliances, even.Overall, CK II is a slick-looking game with a ton of problems underneath. I keep playing it because it is, on a level, addicting, but it's far too broken and mismanaged for me to totally enjoy it or recommend it. Sadly, since the release of Conclave my playtime has taken a nosedive and it's unlikely I'll keep playing. EU4 is at least fun enough without Mare Nostrum to keep playing but with the forced patches and general unlikeability of the gameplay, I can't say I'd tell anyone I know to play CK II. Oh well, at least we'll always have CK 1.

content:
y 14, 2015
												It's easy to start up CK II and not get what the fuss is about. Another Euro-centric medieval simulator, like we haven't seen that before. With a snail pace and no sprawling, Total War like combat, it seems more like a "watch time pass" simulator than a game.But you start a game nonetheless. You chose to start as a small, independent region - maybe the one where you or your ancestors hail from - glory to the motherland and all that. And you just want to learn the ropes, no need to get into anything large. The game starts; you press play and fiddle with the speed. Nothing happens. You leave it on high. Minutes pass; nothing happens. 'OK', let's see what this button at the top left does. You spend the next half hour fiddling with all the info there, trying to make sense of it. From time to time, pop-ups show up, detailing little events that seem to have no impact on the game. 'Oh, cool. This random courtesan fancies me. Who friggin' cares?'.But one message catches your eye - the neighboring ♥♥♥-hat has decided he likes your lands and he'd like to make them his lands. You quickly raise your impressive army only to watch in horror as ten times as many butcher them with ease. Your dynasty ends with its founders head on a pile. Game over.OK, that went as well as can be expected - can't be be blamed for not winning with the small guy on the first time. You start up another game, this time as the biggest, baddest nation that you see - what greater joy could there be than to steamroll all your punier neighbors into fine grains of dust? As the game starts, you watch with greedy eyes as the gold rolls into your treasury. 'Yeah, time to build some ♥♥♥♥'. 'What? It takes one year, costs that much and increases my army by ♥♥♥♥-all percent in this region only?? Screw that, time to slaughter some franks'. 'OK, diplomacy, declare war... Why is it greyed out? Casus Beli??? WTF is that?'. But no matter, while you were scouring your memory of high-school Latin, the guys to the south have graciously decided to bring the fight to you. 'Pathetic basters, they're like half my size. This is going to be fun'. You raise your levies and merge them into one big glob. 'That skull must mean I'm one deadly S.O.B' you think to yourself. And you march to meet them head on, only to see your guys start to die off before you even get there. 'Doesn't matter' you think to yourself, 'I still outnumber them 2:1'. By the time your armies meet, it's more like 1.5 to 1, and you still barely beat them. But you do. Time to reap the rewards...Your peasants have taken up arms against you.Your vassals have risen up to lower crown authority.Your king has died, only to be inherited by a possessed dimwit.You have been excommunicated.The franks have decided that that small little province on the border is theirs and they are willing to drown you in blood for it.Game over.At this moment you are fuming. You steel yourself - this stupid game isn't going to get the better of you. You start thinking, 'what's the best starting point?'. You start again, this time as a count in province deep in the heart of a stable empire. You start slow, making friends with everyone. Then your lord and brother dies, making you the new Duke. 'Oh, so I don't have to attack everyone to take their land'. You make a mental note. The years pass; through claim fabrication, key marriages and poisoned wines you grab a few more adjacent duchies. A few gold coins later and you are the King of Bavaria.This makes the emperor uneasy. He demands that you release a duchy that he claims is rightfully his. You're too weakened from your last conquest to fight him - and it's just a small province anyway. You grin your teeth and accept his demands. And the years pass again; your line is well loved and respected by your emperor and fellow vassals. You are seen as a keen supporter of his Imperial Majesty. But the strangest thing keeps happening. All the bright, attractive or strong princes, they never seem to make it pass infancy. As generations pass, the crippled, the dim and the feeble seem to favored by some unseen force and raise to the crown. Unsurprisingly, your fellow lords are not happy with this rule.The time has come. You start a movement, to replace the inheritance law with an elective one. A bloody civil war erupts and, after many years, you emerge the victor. You are now next in line to become the most powerful man in Europe. Just. one. more. assassination.And... the Huns happen. Your empire is too weak and you fail to protect your lands against the scourge.GAME OVER.It's morning. You have to go to work in about an hour. You call in sick.You probably are...

content:
er 14, 2015
												An Indian family fleeing from oppression in their home province found asylum in my Kingdom of Norway. Why not, I thought. The father of the family was a decent warrior, so I allowed him to command troops in battle. He distinguished himself in many wars over the years and was awarded one of the recently conquered counties in Northern Germany. He continued to serve me loyally and has even converted to Norse religion. For his service I gave him a duchy to rule. Generation after generation his descendants continued to marry local nobles.Now, nearly two centuries later, Germany is ruled by white dudes in turbans who think they're Indian, worship Norse gods and train War Elephants. Breaking history has never been so much fun!I started playing CK2 during a free weekend. It looked like something I might like, so I gave it a try. I bought the game the next day along with several DLCs and never stopped playing. CK2 has now climbed to number 1 of my most played Steam games, in spite of being in my library for less than a year. I don't recall another "game addiction" that lasted this long for me. And there is the fact that nearly 400 hours into the game I've only played as one of the many game religions, one of the numerous cultures (disregarding the training scenario). Playing as a different religion, culture, starting location, starting rank changes the way you play the game. You could even start your second play through in the exact same character as last time and the way things will go will be entirely different. This game is more complex than any other strategy I've played before. It takes a while to take it all in. Luckily there are in-game hints to what every screen means and what every button does (you can switch these off later, but I found myself checking every now and then). There is also a tutorial campaign that will teach you how to play.What adds to the fun greatly is the fact that you play as a specific character. Their traits and abilities make them more appropriate for certain roles within the Kingdom than others. The current King might make a better priest than military commander, but you don't say that out loud in front of your liege (or their spymaster). Once your character dies, you play as the heir to their titles, this being usually one of their children, depending on the hereditary laws of your realm.Feel like expanding your Empire? You don't necessarily need to wage war to achieve that. Why don't you marry your eldest son to that second daughter of the neighboring empire and then make sure the first-born daughter (already married) has a little accident before she has children? However as I am not the patient type I prefer marching my armies into enemy territory and be done with it. What I love about the battles is that the smallest thing can change the outcome of the battle (much like in history). The commander of your strongest flank was killed shortly after the skirmish began and his confused troops now run around the battlefield like headless chickens? Well, s**t happens. There is always a chance, however small, that things will go wrong. It's up to you to play the odds (don't put your only heir in battle, especially while he's sick) and have a backup plan in case things don't go your way or you might end up losing your realm, or the entire game. Once I lost a major battle and most of my personal army. One of my vassals decided now was the good time to revolt, my stronger neighbor saw it as an opportunity to invade and on top of that a peasant uprising started in one of my counties. Bottom line - I lost it all and had to make tribal huts in Norway my capital, which was a bummer after living in a mighty castle in Western France for two generations.The good news is you can appoint commanders as you see fit, provided your authority within the realm is strong enough to do so. Each of the several types of troops (and culture specific special units) has a different attack and defend stats and these evolve as you research technologies and construct special buildings. Your commanders can employ various tactics during battle, some of which depend on their personal traits and/or martial capability. There are many situations you will find yourself in - often thanks to random events, most of which require very specific conditions to be met first. Many events are bound to a specific time and realms that existed at that point. I will not spoil these for you because I found it to be a lot of fun to face some of them followed by a palm on the forehead and an exclamation: “Of course, I (sort of) remember this from history lessons!”I’ve always been interested in history and considered my knowledge of geography very decent and yet I’ve learned a lot of new facts by playing CK2. My natural curiosity took over and I've since researched many medieval realms and rulers online.If you’re feeling competitive then know that achievements are only awarded if you play on Ironman mode. So please make sure that if you come across a player with some of the most difficult of achievements you salute and/or bow as appropriate.At some point you might find yourself lying on your death-bed. Your son and heir might be an imbecile, your younger brother has possibly convinced half of your court he'd make a better King than you and yet you’ll enjoy every minute of it. This game has my full recommendation.If this looks like something you might like then give it a try. But be warned - You might be buying the new number 1 in your library and may thus face the "Should I do something meaningful with my day or should I finally become the King of England?" decision. And we both know it can only go one way from there.

content:
ber 13, 2015
												I'm going to tell you a brief history of the magnificent and prestigious Pasta family; one of the most prevalent Venetian trades families that reigned Venice on and off for some 600 years. Throughout their years and with a very sordid and complicated family tree the Pasta family (stemming from their patriarch, Serene Doge Spaghetti I "The Fat") came to amass a previously unthought-of level of wealth. Legend has it that in the late 11th century Venetian spending ground to a complete halt as the city-state had quite literally too much money and not enough places to invest in. A ruthless and cunning family, the Pasta family spared no expense in making sure their trade ports were renowned the world over. If money was being spent in the Mediterranean, the Pasta family got a cut; to do business and avoid them was difficult. To avoid Venice altogether was impossible. While avoiding open conflict as much as they could, the Venetians did get in a few trade squabbles with the Amalfi, only to render the Greek patricians an afterthought when it came to doing business in the Mediterranean. Using a mix of intrigue and some well-placed military show-of-force, the Pasta patricians were able to get a monetary lock on almost the entire Mediterranean Sea, and were even looking to find a weak county along the Red Sea to capture so as to expand their trade empire into India. Venice made many political and cultural strides in southern Europe, notably by turning its back on Roman Catholicism in 1207 to adopt the Cathar heresy. This did very little to dissuade people from trading with them, however, as Rome itself was home to a particularly busy Pasta trade port for several hundred years at that point. It wasn't until Serene Doge Cavatappi III in 1349 did cracks begin to form in the illustrious Pasta mansion, so to speak. Through a series of marriages to various Saxon and Bavarian princes the Pasta family came in posession of a few counties in mainland Europe; far away from warm, balmy climate of Venice. Sitting on a veritable mountain of gold at this point, the Venetian powers that be tended to ignore their lands to the north, and left it in the capable hands of their respective rulers. After Penne IV, son of Cavatappi III lost the election to become the next Serene Doge (an event that did happen a few times during the 600 year Pasta tenure, but few and far in between), he decided to turn his back on Venice altogether and tore his family's ties from the Republic. Adopting a few of his rightful counties in Bavaria and suffering a hard but brief blow from the bizarre Sunset Invasion, Penne and his kin lived in a financial nightmare. While by no means broke, the family now had a mere fraction of the wealth they amassed during their mainstay in Venice. The reason not much has been written about the Pasta family is because after this exodus the dynasty pretty much lost all of its prestige and money. Left with a few counties in Saxony (which were quickly overthrown by their bigger and more powerful Frankish neighbors) and no historical records left over save for a few manuscripts found in the wine cellar of the old Pasta mansion (discovered only recently), the Pasta family became a cold, stale remnant of what it once was. The only surviving history of the family for a while was of its brief stay in mainland Europe, which was far from glorious. ...I did all of this by clicking things on a map and looking at spreadsheets. 10/10 would create a grand trade empire only to fade into obscurity and have a terrible score at the end of the game again.

content:

 Crusader Kings II Name  - Crusader Kings IIGenre - Grand StrategyPersonal Opinion - The best strategy game there ever was! This is a pretty big game and this is my first review, so I won't delve into it too deep!  Also time played is not true, I have played this game quite a lot offline, unfortunately it does not show offline play hours. Review Crusader Kings II, a game where you can be a King, a Duke, a Count, or even an Emperor, with each level of nobility bringing a new level of difficulty, whereas if you start as a Count, you may start with only one province and depending on where you start you might end up being a vassal to someone else or even have some of your own!Given that you are a vassal, you  may   will  have to compete with other vassals, who will either be lower or higher than you, in some cases you might join a faction with other vassals to try and force the current leader of the country to do things, such as lowering taxes and gaining independence, if you gain enough support you can get things in motion by issuing an ultimatum to the Emperor/King/Duke asking for these things, and if they refuse, you will be able to start a war to get it happening.Then there's marriage, you can just about marry every single person in your kingdom, given that they aren't the same sex as you and they are 16 or over, however you can arrange a marriage for people under 16 (Betrothal).Of course it doesn't just end there, after marriage you can have little clones of yourself (Kids), and build your dynasty, then marry em' off and possibly inherit more land!Also, there are some awesome events that are random and pretty fun. Such as being a lunatic and appointing your horse as your chancellor, or giving birth to the anti-christ. Also, being an absolute tyrant and just murdering your way to the top.Why not discover the "What if" part of history, reclaim the Old Roman Empire, make Britain actually conquer the world, kill the pope, conquer the papacy, restore the persian empire. DLC List  Sword of Islam [www.ckiiwiki.com] Legacy of Rome [www.ckiiwiki.com] Sunset Invasion [www.ckiiwiki.com] The Republic [www.ckiiwiki.com] The Old Gods [www.ckiiwiki.com] Sons of Abraham [www.ckiiwiki.com] Rajas of India [www.ckiiwiki.com] Charlemagne [www.ckiiwiki.com] Way of Life [www.ckiiwiki.com] Mods Just thought i'd share a couple of the best Crusader Kings II mods with you! A Game Of Thrones [citadel.prophpbb.com] - Wiki for A Game Of Thrones [www.ckiiwiki.com] CK2Plus  - Wiki [www.ckiiwiki.com] Pros Ability to do so muchThe scale of this game is unbelievableA complex and rewarding system of internal and international diplomacyAlways challengingEncourages storytellingOpen-ended structure lets you pursue your own goalsGreat mods out there Cons Underwhelming campaign endingNeedlessly complexClumsy interfaceManeuvering large armies can get awkward Rating With all that Crusader Kings II has to offer I'm going to have to give it a  10/10

content:
28, 2016
												Do I recommend this game?Yes, truly I do. Its an awesome game. It develops every single aspect of a strategy game set in the past that are left out of other games. You can have families, friends, allies, non-aggression pacts. You can imprison, execute and banish annoying vassals, you can marry yourself with the daughter of the King of England, and  through the descendants of that union get a claim on his lands. The game is varied, as you an set your game in various time periods across history with hundreds of different factions. You can be a Mongolian Khan or a Holy Roman Emperor just as much as you can be a count in Iceland with no wealth, armies or power. In most strategy games, who YOU in an empire is mostly irrelevant. In the CIV series you're simply a great leader of your nation that rules it forever. Or in the Total war series, you can have a defined character bu everything about him is mostly out of your control or irrelevant. in CK2, all the focus is on your family, as it should be. Your daughters can be married to secure alliances or become great rulers in their own right. Your sons can lead your armies, and can be giving titles you win through war. Some of your sons will love you, others will only try to seize power for themselves. Every single character as a personality, related to their trait that ACTUALLY MATTERS. Be a jerk, become a tyrant and people will hate you, resent you and might even try to murder you This world feels organic and you truly feel a part of it. For all of those reasons, I recommend this gameHoweverIt cant be denied that this game unfortunately has TONS of issues that affect game play. The kind of which will make you want to scream at your screen at how stupid what just happened was. Complete nobodies who actually like you will have you murdered for no reason or  will get themselves 20000 men armies out of nowhere to attack you even tough they don't have a penny on them or apparent claims on your lands. The AI can be incredibly stupid! They cant ever hold on to a king title without being crushed by continuous groups of rebellious vassals. After a century, ever single important christian kingdom will have an elective system of law. Why? Because its what theirs vassals want and the AI cant handle rebellions. You want to battle certain foreign dynasties across history? Too bad, the AI is also incompetent at keeping themselves alive for any long periods. Most great houses in say, 1066 will have disappeared in a bout a century  which COULD be considered historically accurate but at the same time it makes you feel like you're playing this game alone with no actual competition. The AI for the pope can be brain dead. Calling crusades against Kingdoms in India, forcing crusaders to cross the Persian desert to reach their target!The DLC in this game is horrendous. Its DLC whoring that's EA worthy. You have to pay for portraits and songs in the game!!! PURE AESTHETICS STUFF THAT DOESNT CHANGE GAME PLAY. Are you sick of hearing the same 2 god damn songs in repeat? Pay money.The worst about those DLC is what they offer. Without paying extra, you cant play pagans, you cant play Indians, you cant play muslims and you cant play republics. Thats right, more than half of the starting areas are impossible for the player to play unless they pay extra. Others are simply broken and as such are complete rip offs AND THANK GOD I never bought some of them!! They allow you for 5.49 $ to customize your ruler on regular mode BUT not on Ironman mode. But, thats something you could ALREADY DO THROUGH THE CONSOLE. Its vastly useless! The Way of life DLC makes every single male in your kingdom horny dogs that go after your wife, your heirs wife etc... which means, in a game about dynasties ruling across history, your son might just be the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ son of some random count who, thanks to the seduction focus, repeatedly slept with your wife 35 times right under your nose. The ONLY way to make sure your wives don't end up sleeping with every single man in the Kingdom is to pick a chaste one (trait that I rarely see and that they often end up losing) or a lesbian. Apparently, according to paradox, all women were ♥♥♥♥♥s in these times! Seeing how they refuse to truly fix this, thats the only conclusion I can arrive to. They tried to with a new "reject seduction attempts" system but since theres always a few master seducers running around it doesn't stop anyone. The conclave DLC makes the game way harder and sooo much less fun. The Republic DLC forces you to use seniority succession and nothing else! Always playing 75 years old? isnt that fun???The Sword of Islam dlc should've been in the base game, same for the old gods. There's no excuses to leave so many factions unplayable even at an 1066 start. Theres also new updates. Lots of complaints about the new update regarding coalitions that can make pagans, muslims and christians band together against you because you took a duchy through a religious war. They NEVER make coalitions USEFUL agaisnt the AI, this feature is SOLELY used to stop the player from expanding, forcing you to wait 30 f*cking years for infamy to go off unless youre willing to fight 8 nations at the same time. Shattered retreats make your enemies armies magically undestroyable while they basicly have safe conduit back to their territories. Which means, wars now drag for SO FREAKING longer than they need to because you can't kill their armies! You cant pursue them either because you will never have enough supplies and risk losing men needlessly. Sometimes, your own armies will retreat at the WORST POSSIBLE PLACES. When you raid a coast with boats and your raiders gets defeated, they sometimes retreat further in the AIs territory even tough their boats is RIGHT THERE. Theres as of date NO OPTION to turn those off. You dont like them? too bad. You have to use mods on the workshop and disable ironman mode to be able to play without themIn short?? This game offers SO much and at the same time sucks the fun out of the game with questionable design decisions, horrible dlc, and annoying AI. Is the game fun? Yes. Of course it is. But after several hours, you realize all the shortcoming of this game and you're bound to be annoyed by them. Btw, buy this game on a sale, that game is often on sale at 40% or 30% off (cant remember the percentage) Yet every other day its over 200$ to acquire the "full experience". Just wait a little while and get it on sale

number of helpful: 105 of 163 people (64%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
2, 2016
												Loved this game, I considered it one of the best games I ever played. I also liked some of the major DLC such as The Old Gods, Rajas of India and Charlemagne. Even DLCs that added things I felt should have been there at the start such as Sword of Islam did improve the game. Hell I even liked Sunset Invasion because it made gameplay more interesting in the west even if it is nonsensical. A few of the DLCs did make the game better. There's also some enjoyable mods such as the GOT mod and the Elder Kings mod. I also love many of Paradox's games. It should have been impossible for them to turn me into an annoyed customer.That said the devs have simply made to many changes with patches and DLC that have just made CK2 a lot less fun and they're going to continue changing it. At a certain point all their changes were doing was make everything take longer and be more frustrating to do. The changes to the council, shattered retreats and coalitions for example just make the game more tedious. If the changes you're adding don't make the game fun but just make it last longer then what is the point? All you're doing is annoying the people that are playing and buying your products; you get sick of them changing the game for the worse. That's all without mentioning waiting for them to fix bugs in their new updates, DLC and the ton of cosmetic and sound DLC for the game. The other fact is it must be so offputting for someone thinking of buyng the game fresh. There's just too much DLC. I cannot imagine how offputting all the DLC must be to a new player I mean what is there like 50+ now? I don't get how Paradox don't get that seeing a £30 game with 50+ DLCs with a price of £122 is extremely offputting especially to new players or players that didn't keep up with the DLC. I love CK, EU, HOI and like Victoria but I'll not buy another paradox game. They seem to enjoy releasing DLC after DLC that eventually just end up changing the core gameplay for the worse by making the games more frustrating and take longer. On top of that a lot of the DLC seems to change minor things yet are priced the same as the stuff that makes significant changes.They've ruined EUIV imo, CK2 isn't ruined YET but they've definitely made the game worse than it was and since they're apparently going to be releasing even more DLC for it at this point I've basically braced myself for the game to go more and more downhill. So basically I'll never by another one of their games because I know they'll release DLC after DLC that will eventually suck the fun out of the game I liked. They change things that don't need changing and add things the game was better of without and it's frustrating watching a game you like become worse. If it ain't broke don't fix it would be a good principle for Paradox to start following :(.

												This was my experience:Play a few games but I don't really understand the game. Finally after an hour and a half of going throught the tutorials a second time I figure it out. Start up an empire in Iceland. I don't bother anyone. I marry a Danish girl and help out my father-in-law with a rebelion and a small war but I don't really cause any trubble. The king of Norge (Norway) keeps wanting to start wars though. One day I get a letter, he wants peace as long as I fly his flage. Seeing as my wife was sick and had died a month before and her father was now losing a war I did not have the gold to help him win I had no other choice but to submit and accepted Norge rule. Immediatly the King of Norge invites me to his grand feast. He treats me well and offers me protection and safety. Alpha as ♥♥♥♥ King of Norge fights the Scots who have been bothering me for years. I ask if my son can marry his beautiful daughter who will one day be the Queen of Norge, and without question or hesitation he sends his daughter to Iceland and congradulates me on entering the family. WIth this my son is happy and I can concentrait on my kingdom. Over the next few years I build up a great army and nearly 1000 gold in wealth. However, I am an old man. I fear the fate of my father, I fear that soon I will die. The King of Norge is not a young man either anymore. One day I get another letter. The King of Norge is plaining to invade Scotland. Seeing as my other son married Godwinson (The King of England)'s daughter I was prepared to invade Scotland and claim all of  England and thus most of northern Europe for the King of Norge. I constructed a fleet of ships, hired thousands of men from the country side and some extra mecenaries just in case, and set sail. This time I was prepared for battle, I knew what would come. It was minutes laters as I prepaired my assault that I watched a Scotish fleet came from the deep ocean and landed on my shores and slaughter my people. Half of Scotland fought me in Scotland while the other half banded together and invaded my homeland of Iceland. And that folks is the story of how Crusader Kings II gives you a cookie, lets you eat it and enjoy it before slaping you across the face and wash your mouth out with soap and hot sause. And I'll be god damned if it wasn't the most fun I've ever had. I laughed and I cried. I was filled with joy and then crushed with defeat. I was a king...I was THE KING...and then I was nothing...11/10 would loose everything again

content:
y 10
												CK2 makes Civilization V look like Call of Duty. "Go to war with the other guys!" "Get new stuff!"Crusader Kings 2 is a game where you play as a dynasty with no true goal but survive and prosper in any way until the game ends at 1453.You can start anywhere from the High Middle Ages during William's conquest of England to the Late Middle Ages, during the rise of the Ottomans, and play as anyone minus the DLC-requiring peoples, even a vassal of someone else or a little count to rise to victory.The game offers an entire Europe of filthy infidels and christians to convert and conquer, but as you incorporate more vassals and peoples, your risk of civil war will increase, making the conquest of the known world difficult but possible.You can change succession laws so when your character dies like every filthy king does, you won't have trouble with how the hell the crown keeps itself together when you die. Some kingdoms start with Gavelkind, where your kingdom is split among your children, making the conquest of several kingdoms and the stabilization of the world under your rule a farfetched idea, while others may have more proper succession laws.Endless conquest doesn't exist unless everything is lined up; you need an actual reason to take the lands of your filthy heretic enemies. Someone from your Council can fabricate claims to claim that god damn one person, while if there's a filthy infidel on your borders, you can declare a Holy War (unless you're pagan but i think that's dlc required) to take a big chunk of that filthy infidel's land, but risk his fellow infidels defending their INFIDEL religion.The Pope might also call a Crusade to attack an enemy of Christianity or reclaim the Holy City, while the Caliph of an Islamic belief can call a Jihad. Back at home, you can have marriage ties with other nations to get them to be allied to you for future conquests.Is there an insubordinate vassal about to revolt? Rally those who hate him and those who love you in a plot to end his disobediant life! Of course, it's just been revealed that you plotted to kill him, so now everyone knows you've tried to murder him and he hates you.Your neighbour's heresy got him excommunicated, better not ♥♥♥♥ off the pope.The Pope called a crusade on you! better not ♥♥♥♥ off the pope.The Pope just sent you money for killing the Muslims! Now you can kill more Muslims!Oh.Oh...you've just been conquered by the Mongols.well, all of it has been in vain.And that doesn't even scratch the surface!

He then kills his wife and marries the byzantine emperor's daughter, who promptly dies of syphilis. He then  marries the daughter of the HRE thus forming an alliance with them. He then bides his time until the Empire is at its weakest point. The wait was not long, since 5 years later the Caliph of the Sunni faith called a Jihad for Anatolia. The emperor won the Jihad, but at the expense of most of his armies. The Duke, after waiting patiently for so long struck at the rival family. He raised all of the men of the land and used every last coin enlisting the help of mercenary bands. They marched towards Constantinople to meet the Imperial forces. After winning the battle the duke laid siege to the city. Just as the war was about to be won, syphilis struck again not only killing the duke, but his sons as well, leaving the fate of the dynasty and the war in the hands of a 62 year old, possessed, insane and childless relative. All hope was beginning to fail as the war took a turn for the worst. Then in final attempt at survival he sent the last of his armies to face the larger byzantine force. Then in a stroke of luck during the battle, his troops we able to capture the emperor and his last surviving son. The war ended and the emperors daughter took the throne, the 62 year old then attempted to seduce woman multiple times until finally it suceeded after his 65th birthday. content:
y 22, 2014
												The first thing I did as the King of England was assassinate the King of Scotland. It wasn’t for any particular reason. I had just started running the game for the first time, and wanted to check out the King of where I actually lived. But then I saw the assassinate button. I pressed the assassinate button. There was suddenly a dead Scottish monarch and a massive civil war.Crusader Kings II is a ‘Grand Strategy Game’ by Paradox Entertainment, a lovingly created, complex board game of Europe, where you play as historical character. Unlike other strategy games, where you’re the godly hand that guides a country or force, here you’re a Count, Duke, King or Emperor, with all the extra complexities and joys that brings. You have to handle your lineage – marry, have children, assassinate children, change succession laws – so that the game continues. It is the only must in CKII: create an heir, or on death without one, it’s game over. The rest is really up to you. You could try and forge the Empire of Hispania as one of the Spanish Catholic kings, unifying the other catholic nations there and driving out the Muslim rulers. You could play peacefully as the King of Scotland in a different game, only stooping to war when vassals rebel for their own claims on your kingdom. With certain DLC, you could play as Muslim rulers in Africa and Saudi Arabia, Pagan rulers, or even as a patrician, vying for control of the sea highways and port to get the most profit possible.The board deserves some explanation also: unlike many other strategy games, which use hexagonal or square tiles, here real counties are used, such as Gowrie, Cumberland, Middlesex, Badajoz, Leon, and Maine. And they aren’t just bits of land to get to make your Kingdom look bigger: they hold cities, castles and religious buildings that will increase the size of you or your vassal’s levies (army) when annexed and your income, from tax. You can even improve and build new holdings in these counties, to increase both of these. This is one of the many ways you spend your gold, along with creating kingdoms and duchies, hiring mercenaries, bribing the pope (yup!), assassinations, ect.Though out the game, you will be collecting this gold from the taxes, which is the commodity you will be using most often. Also throughout your characters life, he’ll gain Prestige and Piety: both add to your end game score, which you can use to measure just how well you’ve done after playing all those hundreds of years. Both also act like currencies, with you gaining prestige and piety from certain wars and events, but losing them with other events such as destroying kingdom titles (prestige), creating empire and kingdoms (piety) and reforming pagan religions (piety). Upon your characters death, they add to your score – not, however, a reason to die early.War is enjoyable in Crusader Kings II, but possibly not as important as in other strategy games. You can’t declare war, willy nilly. You must have a cause for war, the ‘cassus belli’. This at first feels very restrictive, as in some catholic countries, the only clear way to expand into neighbouring catholic nations is through the slow fabrication of a claim on the county. But eventually it blossoms into the complex strategy, as you juggle where to war with, with what cassus belli, to what end. It becomes delightfully full of opportunities. The Catholic Kingdoms can declare Holy Wars against Pagans and Muslims and claim their land, along with participating in the Crusades the Pope occasionally calls. You also have ‘De Jure Claims’, where you can conquer counties and land that belongs to the predefined ‘de jure’ duchies, kingdoms and empires, depending if you are a Duke, King or Emperor. Pagans can conquer any bordering counties, or subjugate entire kingdoms once in a life time. There is a treasure trove of reasons to war. And with your army, you can choose who leads the armies, and whether to engage them in battles against other armies, or to siege enemy provinces in the war. But it isn’t the only way to gain land: ensuring you’re the heir to the kingdom through assassinations and plots; through offering vassalization to the weaker, smaller independent rulers nearby. But wars are one of the more enjoyable points in the game, as long as you know how to handle them. There really is no better feeling than slowly building your independent duchy into a sprawling Empire over the years.It is important to say that all the rulers on the map are actively acting towards their own goals, with the games superb AI letting hundreds of characters act and change Europe, even in places far from where you are playing. It is sometimes enjoyable to pause the game, and just look around the map, at what’s happening far away. Seeing distant kingdoms fracture, far of empires grow, really gives the game a sense of scale that is great.And in multiplayer, you can have friends play in any of the Kingdoms, replacing one of the AI rulers. It can be incredible fun, with you playing as different Kingdoms, competing as you expand. You can choose whatever way you want to play with friends – you can assassinate them, declare war on them, or offer to join their wars. If they play as the same culture or religion, you may want to help them, to spread it, or fulfil goals that will help you all. With me and a friend playing Norse Pagans (Old Gods DLC), we started trying to expand my kingdom so that it controlled enough holy sites to reform the religion and grant us much needed security for successions. We’ve also had to aid each other during widespread civil and international war and bail each other out. It’s incredibly satisfying to bail your friends’ kingdom out of an independence war, and know they owe you one when you want to take over a nearby kingdom.The downsides of the game is the initial bafflement due to the complexities of how to combine all the systems for your own benefit, and the occasionally irritation caused by wars for the kingdom after succession. Multiplayer also requires all other players must download the host save file every time they play, which can be a slow, but is thankfully all handled in game.This game is one for those who wish to carve a story and a kingdom out of Europe, and are willing to learn through all the complexities and systems to do so. Once the game finally clicks and you’re away with it, it really is a magnificent game. Whole heartedly recommended.

content:
er 25, 2013
												This is something of a Gateway game to take people into the genre of Grand Strategy games in my opinion, starting you in the place of a feudal lord, merchant republic patrician or as a pagan seeking to reform their faith. I think variety is one of the most important aspects in a game and this game provides hells amount of variety and then some. The scenario is constantly changing, and I literally mean constantly changing as feudal lords die, and new rulers take their place and wars coming from the thin of air to turn the balance in their favor.The game is complicated to grasp at first, and requires some dedication and willpower to see through the initial shock of all the concepts, but it can very much be compared to team fortress and all the new weapons and learning things bit by bit. Same concept of learning, and if you ever master this game there will always be Europa Universalis IV to move onto with the save converter, or if you're feeling bold, Victoria 2.Start your character fresh with ruler designer with only yourself to expand it, and in two hundred years it could become THE leading dynasty. Pick up the Old gods and take the Norse sons of Ragnar and conquer Scandanavia and maybe even Britannia, France and the Holy Roman Empire. This is the game where you aren't restricted by anything, and in a series where alternate history is the norm.Edit: My only concern is that much of the game is locked away under DLC. While I love supporting a developer like Paradox I think I should also offer warning that playing without any expansions will limit much of your variety. I started playing the game when it originally came out and bought the DLC as they came out, but the price will seem daunting to those coming into the game. If you're just coming into the game without knowing anything, I'd recommend grabbing two DLCs in particular: "The Old Gods and The Legacy of Rome."
